III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Program statement
Title
1

Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4109
Section (1) An institution shall have and follow a current written program
Description statement which specifically addresses all of the following:
(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care,
safety, and supervision, methods for addressing residents' needs,
implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Two youth AWOL frequently together. Youth was brought back to
the facility 9/18/24 even though his bed was closed 9/11/24. One
youth has been sticking items and their genitals in the other
youth's buttocks. This may occur while AWOL. Both youth have
brands on their bodies from branding each other.
Investigation Interviews:
On 09/19/2024 an in-person interview was held with Lead
Supervisor at Wolverine Human Services. Chief Administrator
participated via telephone. Chief Administrator advised that both
Youth A and Youth B frequently AWOL from the facility. A picture
of some sort of a burn or branding that appeared on both youth
was shown by Lead Supervisor.
On 09/19/2024 telephone contact was made with Complainant.
No additional concerns were noted.
The following interviews were completed onsite at Wolverine
Human Services on 09/19/2024, along with the DHHS
Specialist unless otherwise noted.
An interview was held with Youth A. He reported that he does not
recall or remember when he got the “burn” on his body and does
not know what happened. He went on to say that he got it at
“my abando”. He described this as an abandoned house in the
community that he goes to when he is AWOL. He stated both he
and Youth B were living in this house for about a week. He
denied that any other persons were staying there with them. He
described the house as red, with no locking door, an upstairs,
kitchen, three bedrooms and a back porch. He denied knowing
the address to the house. He reported that Youth B also got a
“burn” like him and stated they burned each other. He stated they
used a “cold thing” that they got from Dicks Hardware. He
reported that he and Youth B got on Bus # 563 to go and get
something to warm the house up, but it ended up being cold.
Youth A stated that it did not hurt, and they branded each other at
the same time. He reported it did not bleed but did hurt for a
2

minute. He stated he does not know why they did it to each other.
Youth A denied Youth B or anyone else touched his butt or put
anything in his butt. He denied being afraid of anyone at
Wolverine Human Services. He lastly confirmed that staff try to
discourage youth from going AWOL and try to keep all youth at
Wolverine safe. Youth A was interviewed again and stated that he
did not want to go for a medical evaluation. Youth A again denied
Youth B or any other youth have touched him inappropriately or in
any sexual manner.
An interview was held with Youth B. He reported he goes AWOL
from Wolverine because he “feels like it” and “wants to be with his
friends”. He denied that he goes anywhere specific, but “just
goes”. He reported he has “a bando” in the community but isn’t
going there anymore. He reported the house is on the street with
“D/X”, but was unwilling to provide further description or explain
the meaning of D/X. He confirmed that Youth A was also at the
house but denied any other youth or adults were there. He stated
they stayed in the house for about five days. Youth B reported
that while they were in the house they were just sleeping, eating,
vaping, smoking cigarettes and weed. Youth B reported that Youth
A would get food from the manager at McDonalds and they would
ask people on the street for other items. When asked about the
burn he confirmed both him and Youth A have the burn, but stated
it was an accident. He reported he was using a device that was
obtained from the hardware store when it happened. He stated he
and Youth A caught the bus to get the device. He reported they
asked people on the street for money in order to buy the device.
He stated they wanted to warm the house up a little. He recalled
that the police arrived and told them to come out and returned
them to Wolverine. Youth B denied that there was any sexual
activity that occurred between him and Youth A. He stated “I’m
not gay, I have a girlfriend”. He reported Youth A told him that he
was raped and beat up by Youth C. Youth B denied that he or
Youth A told any of the staff about this. He stated Youth A told him
that Youth C took him to an abandoned house in the area and
raped him on more than one occasion. He denied that anyone
knew, but then referenced a lady down the street named Adult 1.
He refused to share more information about Adult 1 and just
started to laugh. Youth B denied being afraid of any of the staff
and stated he feels safe in the building. He confirmed that staff
tell the residents in the program it is not safe in the community and
try to discourage them from going AWOL. He further denied any
staff has told him or other youth not to come back to the facility
after AWOLing.
3

On 09/19/2024 a video interview was completed with Youth C.
He denied engagement in any sexual behavior with Youth A or
any other youth at Wolverine. He admitted he would go AWOL,
but denied engaging in any type of inappropriate sexual contact
with Youth A.
On 09/24/2024 a case conference was held to discuss the safety
concerns of Youth A and Youth B and the likelihood of the
burns/brands being marks of human trafficking. DHHS Specialist
2 participated in the meeting and advised that the marks/burn is
not consistent with any markings in the data base that would
indicate a human trafficking branding.
On 09/24/2024 a video conference was held with assigned Foster
Care Worker1 and Foster Care Worker 2. No additional
concerns were noted.
The following interviews were completed onsite at Wolverine
Human Services on 10/03/2024, along with the DHHS
Specialist unless otherwise noted.
An interview was held with Youth D. He reported Youth A and
Youth B go AWOL together all the time and they only come back
to Wolverine to eat and sleep. He confirmed staff does not tell any
of the youth to leave the building and staff always tell them about
how dangerous it is to AWOL. He reported feeling safe at the
agency and denied observing staff hit youth or talk bad to them.
Youth D did report that Youth A told him a couple of weeks ago
that Youth B raped him and put a sex toy up his butt. He denied
knowledge of where this may have occurred. Youth D also
reported that Youth B was saying that it was not him that raped
Youth A, but it was Youth C. He was told by Youth B that there
has never been any sexual contact between he (Youth B) and
Youth A. Youth D does not believe Youth A is afraid of Youth B as
he keeps going AWOL with him.
Youth E was interviewed. He reported staff do not tell the youth
to leave the facility and the boys that go AWOL just go AWOL on
their own. He confirmed that staff try to talk people out of going
AWOL, but some youth still go AWOL. He denied he has
observed any of the youth going AWOL lately. He confirmed
Youth A and Youth B reside at the facility, but stated he has not
seen them recently.
Chief Administrator was interviewed. She advised that both
Youth A and Youth B declined medicals when they returned to
4

Wolverine. She reported there are no incident reports or video
footage of Youth A being sexually assaulted by Youth B or anyone
else. Chief Administrator reported that she believes if anything
happened it occurred while they were AWOL. She reported Youth
A has staff with him all the time while he is in the building and on
the grounds of Wolverine since he is on 1:1 supervision. A safety
plan was discussed regarding the youth.
Staff 1 was interviewed. He reported Youth B will AWOL saying
he needed to go get weed or a breeze pen to smoke. He denied
Youth B has ever given him any problems but reported that he
can't stay put at Wolverine and thinks being in the community is
better. Staff 1 confirmed that he attempts to convince the youth,
specifically Youth B, not to AWOL because the neighborhood is
bad and it's not safe. He denied he has ever told the youth to
AWOL, nor has he heard other staff tell the youth to AWOL. He
would try to redirect the youth before they AWOL. He stated the
youth know staff can't put their hands on them to stop them so the
youth will AWOL. Staff 1 could not recall the events of 9/18/24
specifically, but he shared the process when a youth goes AWOL.
He reported staff will follow until the youth is out of sight and then
write an incident report and contact law enforcement. Staff 1
stated when Youth A and Youth B return, they will often refuse
medicals. He denied hearing anything about Youth A being
sexually assaulted.
On 10/17/24 a Closing Case Conference was held with DHHS
Specialist. No findings of abuse or neglect were found.
Documents reviewed:
On 09/22/2024 DHHS specialist and I received an email
correspondence from Chief Administrator. It documented the
following:
• DHHS staff previously investigated similar allegations of
sexual assault that Youth A made against another peer.
There were no findings.
• Youth A is on 1:1 supervision since his initial intake date.
• Youth B stated he was not going to go to the doctor for the
injury. This is typical for behavior for Youth B. The agency
has made attempts and so has the foster care worker and
the court.
• Youth A originally agreed to go to Urgent Care if he could
get McDonalds, but later changed his mind and did not go.
• Both Youth A and Youth B have refused all attempts to
obtain a medical exam at this point.
5

• The bed of Youth A was closed on 9/9/24 because he was
gone for more than 24 hours. Calhoun County placed him
with Wolverine again on the 10th, despite the facility
strongly voicing their concerns for his increasingly unsafe
behaviors and inability to keep him safe when he continues
to AWOL multiple times a day.
• The bed of Youth B was closed on 09/11/24 because he
was gone more than 24 hours. Muskegon County placed
him with the facility again on the 9/18/24, despite the facility
voicing concerns for his continued unsafe behaviors.
Wolverine Supervision Policy: Indicates the primary job of all
staff is to maintain adequate coverage and Line of Sight of all
youth. Specifically, this means that youth are never left
unattended for any amount of time so staff can view all behavior of
the youth. This ensures youth will not be abused; sexually,
emotionally and/or physically.
Wolverine AWOL Policy: Staff will make efforts to verbally
redirect truanting youth and offer support and alternatives to
truancy. If a non-supervising staff is available, they will walk with
the youth and continue to provide support and redirection. Staff
will immediately notify the Youth Care Specialist Supervisor on
duty when line of sight is lost, no later than 15 minutes after line of
sight is lost. The Youth Specialist Supervisor will contact the Lead
Supervisor and Program Management to provide oversight for
incident management. Staff will notify law enforcement and
program director. Specifics about the youth will be provided to
Law enforcement and an Incident Report will be completed.
When youth return:
The appropriate supervising agency will be contacted and all
parties that were notified of the truancy must also be notified at
the time of return.
Analysis At the conclusion of the investigation, there was not sufficient
evidence to support non-compliance with licensing rule 4109-1-c.
Both youth, staff and administrators were interviewed and all of
them reported that agency staff provides appropriate supervision
and follows the written AWOL policy.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
6

Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules.
